concept.title: API
concept.shortdesc: This is an overview of the inBloom REST API: what it is, its features, and the core concepts used to describe it throughout inBloom documentation.

conbody.p: The inBloom REST API is a RESTful, client-server Web service with all the features you should expect in a robust REST API:

li.p: HTTP methods to exchange representations of resources
HTTP response codes to indicate API errors
Built-in HTTP features, such as HTTP basic access authentication
Support of common data interchange formats (inBloom supports JSON and XML)
Hypertext As The Engine Of Application State (HATEOAS) links in response bodies to provide standardized navigation between resources

conbody.p: The inBloom REST API is designed to be a Level 3 RESTful API in the Richardson Maturity Model. For more information on REST, see REST in Practice (J. Webber, S. Parastatidis, I.S. Robinson) at http://restinpractice.com/book.

The primary consumers of the REST API are applications that run on the inBloom platform and the software developers behind those applications. As an application developer, there are two main parts of the inBloom REST API you can use:

li.p: System resources - Used to perform tasks specific to the inBloom platform, such as authenticating a user or returning session information.
Data resources - Used to access education data in the inBloom data store and perform common operations on that data (create, read, update, delete) based on the current users's permissions.

conbody.p: Besides being familiar with REST, you should be comfortable with XML and terms related to XML schemas. Descriptions around the data resources in the REST API often overlap with common XML terminology.
